repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Currently `deepcopy` hashes every single tables it copies so it can be
reused. For tables of mostly unique items that are non recursive, this
hashing is unnecessarily expensive

Solution:

Port the `noref` argument from Vimscripts `deepcopy()`.

The below benchmark demonstrates the results for two extreme cases of
tables of different sizes. One table that uses the same table lots of
times and one with all unique tables.

| test                 | `noref=false` (ms) | `noref=true` (ms) |
| -------------------- | ------------------ | ----------------- |
| unique tables (50)   | 6.59               | 2.62              |
| shared tables (50)   | 3.24               | 6.40              |
| unique tables (2000) | 23381.48           | 2884.53           |
| shared tables (2000) | 3505.54            | 14038.80          |

The results are basically the inverse of each other where `noref` is
much more performance on tables with unique fields, and `not noref` is
more performant on tables that reuse fields.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
---When `false` (the default) a contained table is only copied once and all references point
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,9 +49,13 @@ end
 ---
 ---@generic T: table
 ---@param orig T Table to copy
+---@param noref? boolean
+---When `false` a contained table is only copied once and all references point

comment_data.body: Might be worth including when/why one might want to use `true` (i.e. the same text in the PR description, if a table contains unique/non-recursive values).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -56,9 +49,13 @@ end
 ---
 ---@generic T: table
 ---@param orig T Table to copy
+---@param noref? boolean
+---When `false` a contained table is only copied once and all references point
+---to this single copy. When `true` every occurrence of a table results in a new
+---copy. This also means that a cyclic reference to `deepcopy()` can fail.

comment_data.body:
Is it worth adding a practical hint re:

> noref=true is much more performant on tables with unique fields, while noref=false is more performant on tables that reuse fields.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1907,15 +1907,20 @@ vim.deep_equal({a}, {b})                                    *vim.deep_equal()*
     Return: ~
         (boolean) `true` if values are equals, else `false`
 
-vim.deepcopy({orig})                                          *vim.deepcopy()*
+vim.deepcopy({orig}, {noref})                                 *vim.deepcopy()*
     Returns a deep copy of the given object. Non-table objects are copied as
     in a typical Lua assignment, whereas table objects are copied recursively.
     Functions are naively copied, so functions in the copied table point to
     the same functions as those in the input table. Userdata and threads are
     not copied and will throw an error.
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {orig}  (table) Table to copy
+      • {orig}   (table) Table to copy
+      • {noref}  (boolean|nil) When `false` a contained table is only copied
+                 once and all references point to this single copy. When
+                 `true` every occurrence of a table results in a new copy.
+                 This also means that a cyclic reference to `deepcopy()` can
+                 fail.

comment_regular_data.body: Wouldn't this cause unexpected changes since the default of the new ref parameter is false but the current behaviour is to deep copy tables?
Both versions "deepcopy"; the difference is only how the nested tables are stored. And the new behavior (`noref`; do _not_ store tables by reference) is opt-in.

> Both versions "deepcopy"; the difference is only how the nested tables are stored. And the new behavior (`noref`; do _not_ store tables by reference) is opt-in.

Ohhhh I see. Sounds reasonable. Thanks for explaining!

> Wouldn't this cause unexpected changes since the default of the new ref parameter is false but the current behaviour is to deep copy tables?

No, the default behavior (`noref` is `false` or `nil`) is unchanged from status quo.

Forward compatibility: Can we make this a keyword in an `{opts}` table, like optional arguments in general? Having `ref = true` would be nicer then (avoid double negatives), at the cost of breaking the analogy with Vimscript `deepcopy` (which has the opposite default, though, so this is a weak argument IMO).

>  at the cost of breaking the analogy with Vimscript deepcopy (which has the opposite default, though, so this is a weak argument IMO).

It has the same default. Omitted or `false` causes tables to only be copied once.

I'm in two minds about the double negative, I'm happy to change it to `ref` if you insist? What do others think?

> Forward compatibility: Can we make this a keyword in an {opts} table, like optional arguments in general?

Hmm, we most probably may not ever need additional arguments, and if we do, we can allow the second parameter to be polymorphic and decide then if we want to deprecate the boolean version. I also think `vim.deepcopy(x, false)` is a lot less cluttered and easier to read/type than `vim.deepcopy(x, { ref = true })`, especially since given the benchmarks I think `noref`/`ref` is likely to be often provided. Though I'm happy to take on board additional opinions.

> I'm happy to change it to ref if you insist?

I don't insist; I feel more strongly about (but also don't insist on) optional arguments being a keyword table (you never know -- at some point someone may want to skip or include metatables, for example, and then position arguments become a mess). "Less typing" tends to carry little weight in our discussions ;)

> I don't insist; I feel more strongly about (but also don't insist on) optional arguments being a keyword table (you never know -- at some point someone may want to skip or include metatables, for example, and then position arguments become a mess).

Afraid we'll need to agree to disagree on this. It's a small function, so I'm willing to take the risk, and it's a reversible decision anyway. Hope that is ok.

I did a quick check with metatables, and from my rough testing it can net you **up to** 10% perf increase which I don't think is significant. enough since you should probably roll your own copy function if you need those kind of gains.

title: feat(lua): add noref to deepcopy
